instruction: What kinds of spectrum was used in the research on the detection and classification of Cannabis sativa L. in illegal plantations?
Output: The research used Near Infrared (NIR) hyperspectral imaging (HSI-NIR) spectrum for the detection and classification of Cannabis sativa L. in illegal plantations.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used in the research on the detection and classification of Cannabis sativa L. in illegal plantations?
Output: Standard Normal Variate (SNV), Multiplicative Signal Correction (MSC), Savitzky-Golay smoothing, and Savitzky-Golay 1st and 2nd derivatives were used as spectral feature processing methods in the research on the detection and classification of Cannabis sativa L. in illegal plantations.

instruction: What metric was chosen and how far can this metric go in the research on the detection and classification of Cannabis sativa L. in illegal plantations?
Output:
The metric chosen in the research on the detection and classification of Cannabis sativa L. in illegal plantations is sensitivity and specificity. Sensitivity refers to the ability of the methodology to correctly identify positive cases of Cannabis sativa L., while specificity refers to the ability to correctly identify negative cases. 

The research achieved sensitivity and specificity values of 89.45% and 97.60%, respectively, for an external validation set subjected to the s-SIMCA model. These values indicate a high level of accuracy in detecting and classifying Cannabis sativa L. in illegal plantations using the proposed methodology.

instruction: How did the researchers evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of the one-class Soft Independent Class Analogy model (SIMCA) in the research on the detection and classification of Cannabis sativa L. in illegal plantations?
Output: The researchers evaluated the sensitivity and specificity of the one-class Soft Independent Class Analogy model (SIMCA) by conducting an external validation set subjected to the s-SIMCA. The sensitivity and specificity values obtained were 89.45% and 97.60%, respectively. These values indicate the accuracy and reliability of the methodology based on NIR hyperspectral cameras for detecting and identifying Cannabis sativa L. in illegal plantations.

instruction: Can Near Infrared Hyperspectral Imaging (HSI-NIR) combined with machine learning be considered a superior method compared to traditional techniques for the detection and classification of Cannabis sativa L. in illegal plantations, in terms of speed, cost-effectiveness, and reliability?
Output:
Yes, Near Infrared Hyperspectral Imaging (HSI-NIR) combined with machine learning can be considered a superior method compared to traditional techniques for the detection and classification of Cannabis sativa L. in illegal plantations, in terms of speed, cost-effectiveness, and reliability. 

The text states that the current analytical methodology used by the Brazilian Federal Police is expensive and strongly dependent on the expertise of the forensic investigator. In contrast, the methodology based on HSI-NIR combined with machine learning is described as faster and cheaper. This suggests that it offers advantages in terms of speed and cost-effectiveness.

Furthermore, the results of the study demonstrate the reliability of this methodology. The sensitivity and specificity values obtained for the detection and classification of Cannabis sativa L. were 89.45% and 97.60%, respectively. These high values indicate that the methodology is effective in accurately identifying the plant.

Therefore, based on the information provided, it can be concluded that Near Infrared Hyperspectral Imaging (HSI-NIR) combined with machine learning is a superior method compared to traditional techniques for the detection and classification of Cannabis sativa L. in illegal plantations, in terms of speed, cost-effectiveness, and reliability.
